update.description:
This adds some very basic functionality including:

1. An Entity class. Review pull request #3 first, which breaks out the Entity portion.

1. A System class. Review pull request #4 first, which breaks out the Entity portion.

1. A simple server, which essentially performs a no-op.

1. A main executable, which runs the server.
update.title: Server
update.reason: This has grown beyond the orignial intent of the pull request. I need to break this down into smaller pull requests.

content.html: Not right now.

content.raw:
I added a print statement to `UpdateSystems`:

~~~
diff -r 440315cbf401 src/ServerPrivate.cc
--- a/src/ServerPrivate.cc	Tue Apr 10 11:28:05 2018 -0700
+++ b/src/ServerPrivate.cc	Tue Apr 10 16:06:00 2018 -0300
@@ -48,6 +48,8 @@
 void ServerPrivate::UpdateSystems()
 {
   /// \todo(nkoenig) Update systems
+  static int i = 0;
+  std::cout << i++ << std::endl;
 }
 
 /////////////////////////////////////////////////
~~~

Now when I call Gazebo with different settings, I keep getting an inconsistent number of updates. Once it even seemed to enter an infinite loop with the numbers ever increasing and I had to kill it. Calling `-v 0` seems to be the most repeatable, but even that gives crazy results sometimes. Some examples:

~~~
louise@pasokon:~/code/ign-gazebo$ ./build/bin/ign-gazebo -v 0

+++ b/src/ServerPrivate.cc  Tue Apr 10 16:06:00 2018 -0300
@@ -48,6 +48,8 @@
 void ServerPrivate::UpdateSystems()
 {
   /// \todo(nkoenig) Update systems
+  static int i = 0;
+  std::cout << i++ << std::endl;
 }

 /////////////////////////////////////////////////

Now when I call Gazebo with different settings, I keep getting an inconsistent number of updates. Once it even seemed to enter an infinite loop with the numbers ever increasing and I had to kill it. content.raw: Just checking: we're not going to use ign-tools for ign-gazebo then?
content.html: Just checking: we're not going to use ign-tools for ign-gazebo then?

The following works for me on Xenial and increases the test coverage, is the problem related to other OSs?

diff -r 440315cbf401 src/SignalHandler_TEST.cc
--- a/src/SignalHandler_TEST.cc Tue Apr 10 11:28:05 2018 -0700
+++ b/src/SignalHandler_TEST.cc Tue Apr 10 15:54:59 2018 -0300
@@ -16,6 +16,7 @@
 */

 #include "SignalHandler.hh"
+#include <signal.h>
 #include <gtest/gtest.h>

 using namespace ignition;
@@ -29,3 +30,20 @@
   EXPECT_TRUE(handler1.Initialized());
   EXPECT_TRUE(handler2.Initialized());
 }
+
+/////////////////////////////////////////////////
+TEST(SignalHandler, Callback)
+{
+  bool called{false};
+
+  auto cb = [&called](int)
+  {
+    called = true;
+  };
+
+  gazebo::SignalHandler handler;
+  handler.AddCallback(cb);
+
+  raise(SIGINT);
+  EXPECT_TRUE(called);
+}

content.raw: I need to add mocking to properly test sighandler. I could add that to this pull request, but this pr has already grown significantly.
content.html: I need to add mocking to properly test sighandler. I could add that to this pull request, but this pr has already grown significantly.

content.raw:
I'll respond to both mutex questions here.

My goal was to prevent two system updates from occurring on the same server.  I also wanted erroneous calls to Run to be non-blocking. 

So, there is lock in `Server::Run` to prevent two threads from being created.

There is also a lock here around `this->running`,  so that one thread is guaranteed to set running. Other threads will return.
content.html:
I'll respond to both mutex questions here.

My goal was to prevent two system updates from occurring on the same server. I also wanted erroneous calls to Run to be non-blocking.

So, there is lock in Server::Run to prevent two threads from being created.

There is also a lock here around this->running, so that one thread is guaranteed to set running. Other threads will return.

content.raw: Is it possible to test adding a callback and triggering a signal?
content.html: Is it possible to test adding a callback and triggering a signal?

content.raw: How about being more verbose and calling it `SignalHandler`?
content.html: How about being more verbose and calling it SignalHandler?

content.raw: This page doesn't exist
content.html: This page doesn't exist

content.raw: I'm curious why we're unlocking before updating the systems and then locking again, do we not want the mutex to be locked while the systems are being updated? Right now it looks like the mutex is only protecting the `running` variable, but since that's atomic, it shouldn't need protecting, right?
content.html: I'm curious why we're unlocking before updating the systems and then locking again, do we not want the mutex to be locked while the systems are being updated? Right now it looks like the mutex is only protecting the running variable, but since that's atomic, it shouldn't need protecting, right?

Should the mutex protect the whole Run function? If we do the following, we may have the server running in 2 parallel threads, right?

server->Run(1000, false);
server->Run(1000, true);

content.raw: A mutex has been added that protects the creation of the run thread, and setting the running variable in the `ServerPrivate::Run` function.
content.html: A mutex has been added that protects the creation of the run thread, and setting the running variable in the ServerPrivate::Run function.

content.raw: Good point. A `SigHandler` class has been added, the implementation of which avoids static variables and functions. A test with multiple servers has also been added.
content.html: Good point. A SigHandler class has been added, the implementation of which avoids static variables and functions. A test with multiple servers has also been added.

content.raw: Since we're using a static variable for `running`, I believe it won't be possible to run 2 servers in the same process, correct? Should we document this, or even programmatically prevent 2 servers from being created at the same time?
content.html: Since we're using a static variable for running, I believe it won't be possible to run 2 servers in the same process, correct? Should we document this, or even programmatically prevent 2 servers from being created at the same time?

content.raw: I think we have to find a way to make sure this isn't called while the thread is still running. I added a failing test on pull request #7, please take a look. I tried checking for `this->Running()` on the beginning of `Server::Run` but that didn't seem to help. I think we may need a mutex.
content.html: I think we have to find a way to make sure this isn't called while the thread is still running. I added a failing test on pull request #7, please take a look. I tried checking for this->Running() on the beginning of Server::Run but that didn't seem to help. I think we may need a mutex.

content.raw: `public` left out on purpose?
content.html: public left out on purpose?

content.raw: Remove math too?
content.html: Remove math too?

Thanks for the example! I got the same results. I guess the only difference then is the narrowing conversion, since the following fails to compile:

int main()
{
  int a{0.5};
}

main.cc: In function ‘int main()’:
main.cc:3:12: error: narrowing conversion of ‘0.5’ from ‘double’ to ‘int’ inside { } [-Wnarrowing]
   int a{0.5};
            ^

But the following does compile:

int main()
{
  int a = 0.5;
}

Not a big deal here, but it's nice to know for the future.

content.raw:
For POD initialization via `=` is equivalent to brace initialization. At least, that is my understanding.

You can try this:

1. Create a main.cc with:

```
int main()
{ 
  double a{0.0};
} 
```

2. Compile: `g++ main.cc -std=gnu++11`

3. Get the assembly: `objdump -d a.out`, and look for the `<main>` section. It should look like:

```
4004d6: 55                    push   %rbp
4004d7: 48 89 e5              mov    %rsp,%rbp
4004da: 66 0f ef c0           pxor   %xmm0,%xmm0
4004de: f2 0f 11 45 f8        movsd  %xmm0,-0x8(%rbp)
4004e3: b8 00 00 00 00        mov    $0x0,%eax
4004e8: 5d                    pop    %rbp
4004e9: c3                    retq
4004ea: 66 0f 1f 44 00 00     nopw   0x0(%rax,%rax,1)
```

4. Alter the main to use the equal operator, and compare the resulting assembly.
content.html:
For POD initialization via = is equivalent to brace initialization. At least, that is my understanding.

You can try this:

  1. Create a main.cc with:
int main()
{ 
  double a{0.0};
}

  1. Compile: g++ main.cc -std=gnu++11

  2. Get the assembly: objdump -d a.out, and look for the <main> section. It should look like:

4004d6: 55                    push   %rbp
4004d7: 48 89 e5              mov    %rsp,%rbp
4004da: 66 0f ef c0           pxor   %xmm0,%xmm0
4004de: f2 0f 11 45 f8        movsd  %xmm0,-0x8(%rbp)
4004e3: b8 00 00 00 00        mov    $0x0,%eax
4004e8: 5d                    pop    %rbp
4004e9: c3                    retq
4004ea: 66 0f 1f 44 00 00     nopw   0x0(%rax,%rax,1)
  1. Alter the main to use the equal operator, and compare the resulting assembly.

content.raw: I think it prevents a copy construction and also in the case of an int, it would prevent initializing it to `0.5` for example. I've been trying to use braces whenever I can, there are several instances on `ign-gui`, but that is not building on windows yet.
content.html: I think it prevents a copy construction and also in the case of an int, it would prevent initializing it to 0.5 for example. I've been trying to use braces whenever I can, there are several instances on ign-gui, but that is not building on windows yet.
